post_info.post_title: US media trying to influence the elections in Lebanon?

lord tammerlain

I have been trying to follow the Lebanon elections, is Auon likely to win?
 
 Now what about expats, are they being allowed to vote ( ie people who left Lebanon 20 years ago and have not returned)
gamehuis

I visit Lebanon quite frequently, in fact I just came back this morning from a trip there, but their electoral system is still somewhat of a mystery to me. Each municipality can elect a certain number of representatives which are usually chosen from certain religious groups. For example, Municipality A can have 3 representatives in parliament, 1 Christian, 1 Sunni and 1 Shia, while Municipality B can only have 2 representatives which both have to be Sunni etc. In the end the parliament will always be 50% Christian and 50% Muslim. 
 Aoun will probably score some votes, but the big winner will probably be the coalition of Saad Harriri, the son of Rafik Harriri.
 
 And no, expats are not allowed to vote.
georged

I was watching CNN just now and they had a 'Breaking News' story about how Hezbollah is supporting, recruiting and funding Palestinian suicide bombers.
 
 IMO it's an attempt to influence the elections in Lebanon. 
 I mean, what's so 'Breaking News' about it? This information was already well known for months if not years. It's just too much of a coincidence that they report this story 2 days before the elections in Lebanon.

 
 Sounds like a US State Department release that got picked up because CNN's Beirut bureau was looking for air time credit.
Clive14

Sounds like a US State Department release that got picked up because CNN's Beirut bureau was looking for air time credit.
Excuse my ignorance, but what do you mean by "air time credit"? Can you elaborate on what CNN (or CNN's Beirut bureau) gets by covering the story?
georged

Excuse my ignorance, but what do you mean by "air time credit"? Can you elaborate on what CNN (or CNN's Beirut bureau) gets by covering the story?

 
 It's an ongoing internal political battle between media bureaus (offices located in cities and countries other than headquarters) to furnish stories presented by on-screen talking heads. There are star bureaus and backwater bureaus. All forms of media are after audience share and almost anything referring to 'foreign fighter's' is, after US Government policy of blaming all 'terrorist' problems on outside influences, always gets air time. If you listen to news leads, credit is normally given to the contributing bureau or reporter.
 In print media, credit is normally given before the article. Think of it as a fast food place where a 'team member' is recognized with a plaque for outstanding service as an employee. A few plaques and they want the fry cook job.
Clive14

It's an ongoing internal political battle between media bureaus...
OK, my bad. I assumed you meant money or points type credit rather than acknowledgement type credit. It makes sense now. Thanks.
daewoo

I would not be surprised. I would be surprised if it worked, though.
 
 From what I have heard from people I know in the region, anti american feelings have grown since the changes in lebanon. Apparently they do not take kindly to Bushs attempts to step up and take credit for the changes there, despite the fact that we (the US) had nothign at all to do with it.
 
 Gamehuis, ahve you witnessed any such feelings in your visits there, or am I reading things wrong?
 
 
 Allowing expats to vote is generally reserved for elections that we are trying to rig. We made a big push to get Iraqis on the international scene to vote because we felt they were more likely to side with the US and vote for "our guys". Most of the iraqi expats who voted had not been to iraq in years, and will likely never return. Also, if you look at the nations where we set up Iraqi voting, it speaks volumes. The largest base fo Iraqi expats are in Iran. I did not see news reportsa about the Iraqi expats in IRan casting ballots, though the Iranians would probably have even footed the bill for that one.
gamehuis

Gamehuis, ahve you witnessed any such feelings in your visits there, or am I reading things wrong?

 No you're not wrong, both the Christians and the Muslims really don't look too kindly upon the US for taking credit for something which the Lebanese have worked so hard for themselves for so many years.
 
 There's also an underlying sentiment which has to do with the civil war itself. The war was a direct result of outsiders trying to influence the way things ran in Lebanon.
 The people don't ever want a repeat of what happened, so apart from the UN they want nothing to do with outside influence, be it American, Syrian or otherwise.
 Naturally this is easier said than done considering that Syria and Iran still have close ties to Hezbollah, but slowly progress is being made.
 Despite what is said in the media, the leader of Hezbollah is actually considered to be a moderate by many people, including the Christians.

 Sorry, that is either a lie or (more likely), you have absolutly no idea what you are talking about. Every single command level officer that I know that has come back from Iraq has called our tactics there sicening and dishonorable. We put no value on Iraqi civilain lives from a tactical standpoint, instead ensuring low US casualties in order to keep the number of grieving widows and flag draped coffins on the 6 o'clock news to a minimum. 
 
 Our current strategy has untrained, unequipped Iraq "police" on the front lines while US troops hide like scared women behind heavily fortified positions and drive around in heavily armored vehicles.
 
 There is absolutly no honor in how we are fighting this war. You do not end up with 1200 dead soldiers, and 100,000 dead civilians when you are doing "everything posible to hold down the casualties". You end up with 100,000 dead civilains and 1200 dead soldiers when you say "**** the civilians, save the soldiers", which is what we have done in Iraq, and is what we did in afghanistan.
 
 
 I don't expect an REMF to understand things like strategic strike planning, or planning assaults for minimal collateral damage, but if you don't understand it, you shoudl probably not be commenting on it. It is better to remain silent and be assumed a fool than to open your mouth and remove all doubt.

 If anything Iraq has proved this point, if you have a group that is politically oppressed they will resort to violence to achieve their goals. 
 
 Look at Northern Ireland, we(UK) negotiated with Sinn Fien. They then joined the political process, now there is very little violence in Northern Ireland.
 
 I don't like the fact that former killers have now been elected to the UK Parliament but I have recognised that without this form of representation in the Parliament we would probably return to the dark days of the troubles in Northern Ireland.
 
 What would you rather have former killers elected by the people take part in a democracy, with no Violence ?
 
 Or would you rather exclude these people and continue the mindless slaughter ?

 Guard duty on a ship in one of the most secure facilities in 1968 Vietnam?
 
 ~Cam Rahn Bay experienced very little overt enemy activity during the 1968 TET period. On the morning of 31 January, a North Vietnamese Army frogman trained in demolitions and assigned the mission of sabotaging friendly vessels was captured in the harbor. The mayor of Cam Rahn Bay immediately placed the civilian population under strict curfew and limited water traffic by Vietnamese nationals in the harbor area. During the next week, there were numerous sightings of frogman activity in the Cam Rahn Bay area. Elements of the 97th Military Police Battalion, particularly those from the 981st Military Police Company (SD) assisted in the search for infiltrators in the bay.~

 I'm not a left winger but that's a common designation of front-line troops since the beginning of history. In conventional strategy a prime criterion is equating the number of potential losses to force required to secure an objective. When the primary inhabitants are civilians or Iraq army members desperate for jobs, low US loss ratios, the all important political aspect, are easy to maintain by using armor, aircraft, unemployed Iraqis and generally keeping a low profile.
